description: A distant relative of emus and African ostriches.  Found in the grasslands and various other open regions of South America.
//: Clutch sizes are higher, but those are clutch sizes for nests, and nests can contain eggs from multiple females.

description: A miniature rhea.  The appearance of it is distinct enough to easily identify.
//1: Sources say day-1 hatchlings weigh around 75% of their egg mass.

description: The largest species of toucan sporting dark plumage and a bright colored beak.  This bird can be found pretty much all over South America, feeding on fruits and seeds.

//: Copied from the vanilla corvids. ~8 weeks to fledge, but couldn't find any info on how long it takes for them to reach adult size. Sexual maturity is a bad metric as they reach it very late, at 3-4 years of age.

description: A small bird with bright green-colored plumage and a short hooked beak.  This species is widespread throughout all of South America, on top of being quite intelligent and sometimes kept as pets.

//: 12 days to reach independence. Use a multiplier of 4 to our advantage to get a rough estimate of reaching adult size.

petfood.feed: The %s seems to like you!  It runs around your legs and seems friendly.

description: A large parrot sporting beautiful blue plumage.  Intelligent and often kept as a pet.

petfood.feed: The %s seems to like you!  It runs around your legs and seems friendly.

description: A tiny, golden bird bopping around in the canopy of trees.  Its cone-shaped bill tells you it s a seed eater.
//: Values for reproduction and chick growth copied from the cedar waxwing, as no info could be found online.

description: This large flycatcher has a black crown, prominent white eye stripe and a dominantly yellow body.  At almost a foot long, it swoops up a variety of flying insects.
//: Values for reproduction and chick growth copied from the bluejay, as no info could be found online.

description: A drab, robin-sized ground bird with startling red eyes.  More often spotted are their odd oven shaped nests.

One of several species of tinamous present in Brazil.  Although these birds converged into shapes similar to domestic fowl, they are more closely related to the extinct moas, though unlike them, tinamous are capable of flight.
//: 4 broods a year, and we're assuming they're breeding only for half a year. Clutch sizes per nest can reach 16 eggs, but these can be eggs from up to 4 females, so we're taking an average.

description: A medium sized bird with long legs and a small crest.  It lives on the grasslands of South America and is considered the only living relative of the extinct terror birds.
//: 2-3 eggs. 30 days of incubation + 4-5 months for the chick to reach adult plumage.

description: Though its face looks oddly like a chicken's, complete with red wattle, this tan bird sounds nothing like one as it lets out raucous cries of 'chata-ra-ta.'
//: 2-4 eggs per clutch. No info I could get on anything else for this species so we're going with plain chachalacas' values instead.

Nothing about this species specifically, but plain chachalacas' breed between March and September with chicks staying with their parents until October -> we're taking an average of about 5 months to reach independence.

description: A medium-sized speckled bird.  Its bright orange wattle contrasts sharply with the rest of its brown body.

//: Some sources say 6-8 months to reach independence for most guan chicks (others say 2 years, who do I trust?)

description: This black bird carries itself oddly proudly, despite the ridiculous mohawk-like fringe on the top of its head.
